name: Northern Bobwhite
descriptionLong: The Northern Bobwhite, a small game bird with an unmistakable call, has lost extensive amounts of habitat in the central and eastern U.S., leading to an 81% population decline over the last 50 years.
descriptionShort: This quail has lost 81% of its population.
textSources__name: Breeding Bird Survey; Birds of the World

name: Pronghorn
descriptionLong: Pronghorn have been in North America for over a million years and are the second fastest land mammals in the world. Speed and stamina will not be enough to keep our antelope playing on the Great Plains unless they can continue to use their generations-old migratory routes.
descriptionShort: Populations of Pronghorn have shrunk from almost every western state they once occupied.
mapSource: Wild Migrations: Atlas of Wyoming’s Ungulates, 2018, OSU Press
textSources__name: Ungulate Migrations of the Western United States, vol. 1 (2020)

name: Monarch Butterfly
descriptionLong: Monarch butterflies are famous for their epic migrations in the hundreds of millions between North America and Mexico. 80% of this population has been lost since the 1990s. Monarchs that overwinter on the California coast have been hit even harder, declining by over 95% since the 1980s.
descriptionShort: Monarch numbers have collapsed by 80-95% across the country.
mapSource: Semmens et al. (2016); Schultz et al. (2017)
textSources__name: Semmens et al. (2016); Schultz et al. (2017); Butterfly Icon by Bonnie Beach from Noun Project (CC BY 3.0)

name: Greater Prairie-Chicken
descriptionLong: Greater Prairie-Chicken males display to females on “booming grounds,” often sharing these stages with other grouse and pheasant species. Sage-grouse and prairie chickens all require unbroken grassland and sage habitat and abandon their breeding sites when tree cover exceeds 5-10%.
descriptionShort: Once found across the central U.S., this grouse now occupies a fraction of its past range.
textSources__name: Birds of the World; Lautenbach et al. (2017)

name: Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout
descriptionLong: Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout are the southernmost type of cutthroat trout. Like other cutthroat trout, they live in clear, cold streams and lakes. They are threatened by non-native trout, as well as water pollution caused by the loss of grasslands and sagebrush.
descriptionShort: The loss of grasslands and sagebrush leads to pollution of the rivers and streams that Cutthroat Trout depend on.
textSources__name: Western Native Trout’s Rio Grande Cutthroat Trout Status Report (2016)

name: Northern Pintail
descriptionLong: Northern Pintail ducks breed in grasslands. They have lost crucial sites across the U.S., especially nesting places, but also their wintering homes. Pintail populations fell from 10 million ducks in the 1950s to just 1.8 million by 2022.
descriptionShort: Northern Pintails have lost roughly 82% of their population in the last 70 years.
textSources__name: USFWS Waterfowl Population Status (2022); Birds of the World

name: Ring-necked Pheasant
descriptionLong: The Ring-necked Pheasant, a popular game bird, has lost 27% of its population, especially in the Midwest. Destroying intact grasslands often means losing pollinator-friendly plants, endangering food sources for nestlings and adults.
descriptionShort: Ring-necked Pheasants have lost 27% of their population.
textSources__name: Breeding Bird Survey; Birds of the World

name: Elk
descriptionLong: Elk bugles are true calls of the wild. Prior to European settlement, there may have been as many as 10 million elk ranging across North America. Today, about one tenth of that population remains within a fraction of their historic range.
descriptionShort: The Elk's current population is one tenth of its historic size.
mapSource: Wild Migrations: Atlas of Wyoming’s Ungulates, 2018, OSU Press
textSources__name: Ungulate Migrations of the Western United States, vol. 1 (2020)

name: Bobolink
descriptionLong: The distinctive Bobolink, named for the male’s bubbling song, has lost 55% of its population and is on track to lose another 50% in the next 50 years if nothing changes.
descriptionShort: This grassland bird is on track to lose 50% of its population in the next 50 years if nothing changes.
textSources__name: Breeding Bird Survey; State of the Birds (2022)

name: Scaled Quail
descriptionLong: The Scaled Quail, named for the scaly appearance of its feathers, lives in the dry scrublands and grasslands of the Southwest. Loss of vegetation for food and cover, and more frequent droughts, have led to a 31% decline over the last 50 years.
descriptionShort: The population of this western quail has declined by 31%.
textSources__name: Breeding Bird Survey; Western Quail Management Plan (2009)

name: Greater Sage-Grouse
descriptionLong: The Greater Sage-Grouse is an iconic Western grassland bird that captivates us with its distinctive courtship dance. It has lost 60% of its population over the last 50 years.
descriptionShort: The Greater Sage-Grouse, a bird that lives only in sagebrush, has lost 60% of its population.
mapSource: Cornell Lab | eBird; Birds of the World

name: Mallard
descriptionLong: Mallards are widespread but show recent declines. The greatest numbers of North American Mallards breed in the West and Midwest’s Prairie Pothole region (also known as the continent’s “duck factory”). Less than half this habitat remains today.
descriptionShort: Mallards (and other ducks) have lost over half their prairie breeding grounds.
textSources__name: Birds of the World; Doherty et al. (2013)

name: Southern Plains Bumble Bee
descriptionLong: Southern Plains Bumble Bees pollinate many plants in the southeastern coastal plain and Great Plains. Across its range, it is 85% less common than it used to be. This endangered pollinator faces a significant chance of disappearing.
descriptionShort: The Southern Plains Bumble Bee could disappear if declines continue at current rates.
mapSource: Richardson, L. L. 2023. Bumble bees of North America occurrence records database
textSources__name: IUCN Assessments for North American Bombus spp. (2014); Bumble Bee Icon by Beth Lewis from Noun Project (CC BY 3.0)

name: Mule Deer
descriptionLong: Mule Deer herds are faithful to their migratory routes and seasonal ranges, and still roam most of the western half of North America from the Yukon to Mexico. However, populations across the western U.S. began declining in the 1970s. Some of these losses continue due to disrupted migratory routes and changing environmental conditions.
descriptionShort: Disruptions to Mule Deer migrations are one reason many populations have declined across the western U.S. since the 1970s.
textSources__name: Ungulate Migrations of the Western United States, vol. 1 (2020)

name: Regal Fritillary
descriptionLong: Regal Fritillary butterflies are found only in grasslands and reproduce only once a year. Once widespread, they are likely gone from 15 states and continue to decline in most of their remaining range in the Midwest.
descriptionShort: This grassland butterfly has likely disappeared from half its historic range and continues to decline in most of its remaining range in the Midwest.
textSources__name: Regal Fritillary (Speyeria idalia Drury): A Technical Conservation Assessment (2007)
